Port shaft tripped and as a precaution, vessel was diverted into open water.
Vessel steering pumps not operational when testing steering before departure.
Jet boat driver training on river when vessel ran aground. No injuries or damage.
Starboard (stbd) engine was shut down due to stbd shaft alternator dropping out. Returned to berth.
Pilot ladder had numerous loose chocks and treads. Ladder needs replacement.
Passenger vessel near miss with another vessel due to AIS not working. Evasive action taken to avoid collision.
Passenger vessel near miss with another vessel due to AIS not working. Evasive action taken to avoid collision.
Charter vessel returning to port hit submerged object, damaging the stern leg of the outboard motor.
During inflatable rescue boat driver training, driver turning close to shore mistook a wave and fell overboard. No damage or injuries.
Vessel presented with a combination ladder arrangement. The accommodation ladder platform was low, approximately 2.5m above the water.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Main engine could not be started at berth. Pilot ordered check as the response time to start and stop was significant. Departure cancelled and sailing resumed ten hours later following repair.
Pilot ladder non-compliant due to accommodation ladder being a couple of metres above water. IMO requirement is 5m.
During driver training, instructor was driving with two passengers and made a fast turn, resulting in both passengers going overboard.
Crew member sustained thumb injury while manually handling a CTD carriage into position through the cutaway on the trawl deck.

During driver training, crew were simulating patient pickups when vessel turned into wave but failed to accelerate resulting in a capsize. Vessel uprighted and returned to shore. No damage or injuries.
Internet went down and was unable to get updates from electronic publications. OneOcean system was removed but unable to reinstall due to weak internet connection.
Pilot ladder had unsafe rigging. Was lashed to deck with rope and webbing type strop.
Mooring bowline slipped off cleat and boat lurched forward two metres down pontoon coming into contact with bollard on pier 6. Slight dent in ramp. No injuries.
While boarding vessel, passenger slipped on internal staircase and twisted ankle.
Pilot ladder retrieval line rigged aft and below spreader. Pilot ladder secured with small rope.
Crew member in freezer hold carrying a box of frozen fish. He slipped and landed on his hand, resulting in a cut to his right finger with possible fracture.

Yacht caught in heavy seas suffered a rudder malfunction, then lost its anchor and began to drift toward the rocky coastline. A nearby fishing vessel responded to the stricken yacht and rescued the two passengers.
Near miss between two jet boats due to faulty radio.
Last spreader on pilot ladder was bowed. Rest of ladder in good condition.
While performing repairs, a large tool used to apply torque failed and a piece of the toll jaw broke off, falling from height off the working platform to the moon pool below.
Lost power to port shaft while berthing at Picton.
While crew were working to pull up collapsible stanchion, the ship rolled, causing the crane block to swing and hit a crew member. Injured crew member was transported by helicopter to hospital.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Inflatable rescue boat was driven over a broken wave and hit by another, resulting in master and crew persons going overboard. No injuries.
Master appeared to misjudge a turn in the rigid inflatable boat (RIB). Their attempt at correcting course by rapidly changing direction resulted in crew member falling overboard.
Stranded on an iceberg in a South Island lake after his inflatable boat was damaged.
During testing of the ships bilge system, the system was found to not be fully operational. Class has been contacted.
Gangway on vessel damaged at aft end and not fit for use. Has raised edges.
Skipper of fishing vessel cut hand on board, this injury led to septicemia, resulting in several other serious medical conditions.
Crew member presented with shortness of breath and pale appearance. Vessel diverted to Tauranga and crewperson transferred to hospital.
While completing a mooring inspection, one yacht mast stay got tangled with another moored yacht, breaking the mast.
Vessel exceeded 5 knot rule during attempted rescue of two individuals swept out to sea.
Pilot ladder had a number of loose chocks and treads turned underfoot.
Contractor dropped spanner into ship freezer during unloading. No injuries.
The pilot ladder had loose chocks, the steps were rotating and not parallel.

When driving the boat downstream through the channel, the driver went wide on the corner and caught the stern of the boat on a gravel bar. This caused the boat to spin around and get stuck on a gravel bar.
The driver attempted a planned u-turn, the boat dropped off the plane and beached. There were no injuries or damage.
A worker was pushing a freezer tray when the vessel rolled,  causing the trays to slide out, crushing their leg. The master arranged a medvac for the injured worker from the ship.

A bow securing alarm sounded, crew members checked the PLC. There was no influx of water or failure. It was determined that a junction box had come loose resulting in loss of connection to the cleat sensor.
During voyage it was reported that the Ballast Water Treatment System was defective and unable to be used.

The bow blew off causing the vessel to turn sideways into close proximity to other vessels, lines in water and the wharf. When turning to clear the area the vessel hit the stern of a moored vessel with their Starboard stern. Minor damage occurred.

The bow blew off causing the vessel to turn sideways into close proximity to other vessels, lines in water and the wharf. When turning to clear the area the vessel hit the stern of a moored vessel with their Starboard stern. Minor damage occurred.

Training exercise involving the winching of a patient from deck of vessel. While attaching winch hook, vessel was buffeted by a wave causing the hook to make contact with the patient, chipping their tooth.
During training exercise, RIB vessels approached another vessel too fast, causing a collision which punctured the front bag of the RIB. There was no damage to the other vessel.
The vessel was fixed tight to berth when the tide withdrew, causing substantial damage to the vessel. The vessel was taken out to be serviced. No damage to the wharf occurred.
When the vessel was coming into the channel, they made contact with a newly developed sand bar. The vessel was able to move back to deeper water and return to shore. No injuries or damage occurred.

A submerged log was seen in front of the vessel. The skipper made a call that the vessel could not turn safely, the log went under the hull and struck the skegs at the rear. The engines were turned off, the bilge pump was checked. No damage occurred.

When passing a marker the wind and tide pushed the vessel into the marker pole at midships contacting the belting. As a result the marker pole was left on an approx. 30 degree list. No injuries or damage occurred. The harbour aster was notified.
The jet boat grounded while attempting to perform a spin.
Wire parted while crew were securing accommodation ladder for sea passage which resulted in ladder dragging through the water. No crew were harmed.
Engine failed to fire astern and ahead on multiple occasions when approaching and berthing vessel. It was also slow to start when engine did fire. Tugs utilised to slow vessel and berth safely.
Vessel caught side on by wave, rolling the vessel.
Crew was pulling in fish, the hook came out of the fish and hit them in the eye, sustaining bruising.
Jet boat lost control during a turn, resulting in a beaching.

While receiving a sunken line of mussels, a bent hook pinged off the line and hit the crew member on their forearm of left hand resulting in a deep gash to their arm. First aid was applied and then they were taken to hospital for further treatment.
Staff member slipped on vessel stairwell, sustaining a fractured ankle.
MPI issued notice of redirection to vessel due to ballast water treatment system malfunctioning.

Crew member fell from the landing to the deck below (approx. 1.5m height), striking their head on the closed door. The crew member was stabilised in position and an ambulance was called. They were taken to hospital for tests and x-rays.
Master informed that there was a leak in a pipe in the engine room and the main engine needed to be stopped. Anchor dropped and repairs were conducted
Starboard motor lost RPM. Engine room was checked and fault unable to be identified. Steering was unavailable due to starboard motor running steering pump. The vessel was towed to port

The ship was notified of a crew member with suspected appendicitis who was requiring urgent attention. Ships agent notified RCCNZ who arranged for a rescue helicopter to transport the patient to hospital.
Jetboat grounded on riverbank. Passengers were transferred to another boat.
Vessel ran out of gas in the harbour shipping lane and was assisted by Coastguard.

Vessel dragged anchor due to wind strength and made contact with river mouth. The sips engines were restarted, crew mustered and vessel moved clear back into deeper water. The vessel re anchored, there were no injuries or damage.
Crew member grabbed a rope, pulling the front of their finger into the winch. This resulted in the crew member sustaining a finger injury.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
The pilot ladder was in poor conditions with numerous loose chocks causing rotating treads.
Navigational equipment faults reported by pilot.
Fuel was smelt from in the vessel, and was noticed on the floor. The vessel was striped down to find the leak. There was a crack in the top which was repaired.
The pilot ladder was in poor condition with numerous loose chocks and the steps rotating.
While emptying the codend of fish, a crew member's leg was caught between the hatch and the codend which resulted in a crushing injury.
Pilot ladder was in poor condition with numerous loose chocks and steps rotating under foot.
Pilot ladder lowest spreader had loose chocks.
On the way into port, the echo sounder equipment was not powering up. The vessel made it safely into port with pilot onboard. A technician was booked to make repairs.
Vessel was not under operation and separated from mooring line causing it to hit the wharf, damaging its outboard motor. No injuries were sustained.
Pilot ladder was worn and had multiple loose chocks.

Skipper on board passenger vessel in transit to berth heard a bang and felt vibrations. Revs were dropped on the main engine but vibration persisted. Vessel continued to port on minimal RPMs on port main engine.

During process of ordering counter helm to bring vessel back towards the channel centreline a loud bang was heard and vibration felt on bridge. The vessels handling became sluggish. Anchors were deployed and then recovered, tugs assisted the vessel.
Vessel experienced propulsion failure after departure from port. Vessel held fast with support from two tugs. An engine test was undertaken and vessel had a successful engine restart.

There was an escape of ammonia gas from a pinhole leak in compressor discharge line in engine room. Automatic ammonia detection alarm sounded and crew were evacuated. The compressor line was closed down and the area ventilated. The pipe was replaced.
An injury occurred to the crew member's hand, requiring two stitches.
Fatal recreational boating accident.

A jet boat was coming down the river when they clipped a tree protruding from the bank. This caused passengers to collide with one another, and knocked overboard. Injured passengers were medical evacuated to hospital.
Pilot ladder was substandard with steps rotating under foot.
Vessel collided with a swimmer, causing a 18cm scrape to their hip.
Fishing halted due to heavy weather. A large wave broke off the vessel's paravane boom causing it to fall overboard. Vessel returned to port to check for damage.
CCTV footage identified a vessel leaving the port leaving a spotted slick behind the vessel. Port staff responded by deploying two vessels to disperse the substance.
Vessel had just started trawling when a large rope became entangled in the propeller. This caused them to stop instantly.
Vessel made an urgency radio broadcast that they had lost all power. They reported needing a tow if they couldn't get the switchboard working.
Vessel just cleared harbour limits when main switchboard insulation alarm appeared on the IAS. An inspection showed a burnt transformer. Repairs were undertaken and the journey continued.

Fishing vessel broke away from mooring and washed up on the beach. While being towed backwards the vessel made contact with the wharf at Golden Bay due to poor weather conditions and loss of thrust and steering.
Vessel was undergoing planned maintenance when smell of ammonia was detected. As a precaution vessel alarm sounded and crew evacuated.
Hazardous material spilled on the foot of a crewmember, causing chemical burns.
Skipper suffered a medical event and fell, striking their head. RCCNZ were contacted and medvac arranged.
Vessel hit an uncharted rock in the bay, while in gear at idle speed.
While departing the wharf the main engine lost oil pressure and shut down. Vessel was approaching shoreline so anchor dropped. Main engine restarted and vessel continued without further problems.
The crewmember was pulling a pot they were struck in the eye by a loose wire. Basic first aid was applied.
Vessel grounded momentarily while crossing the river bar. There were no injuries or significant damage to the vessel.

The vessels starboard engine lost oil pressure. Engine was shut down and the vessel was returned to port under steam using the port engine. With limited manoeuvrability,  vessel made contact with another vessel at berth, sustaining minor damage.

The vessels starboard engine lost oil pressure. Engine was shut down and the vessel was returned to port under steam using the port engine. With limited manoeuvrability,  vessel made contact with another vessel at berth, sustaining minor damage.
Pilot reported an error with remote piloting, resulting in a near grounding.

Steering issues arose when auto pilot failed, causing vessel's starboard rudder to go hard to starboard. The auto pilot went into alarm and master was unable to regain manual control. Engines were shut down and rudder control was re-established.
Deck channels that containers lock into as door stops failed and containers fell into the sea.

Worker was removing floats from the backbone line during mussel harvesting operations. During this process, the worker cut the back of their left hand with their knife. First Aid was applied onboard, and the worker attended the emergency department.
Contact occurred between cranes two and three. Crane two luffed down onto the back of crane three. Crane limits changed since original inspection before loading commenced.

Vessel misjudged tide inside marina resulting in collision with poles on pier. The skipper struggled to manoeuvre the vessel in the confined space but eventually managed to get off the poles without any further damage to the vessel or marina.
Local wastage and holes found in the web of longitudinal I-beam of the accommodation ladder. The ladder was removed for repair.

Vessel was heading to Waiheke Island and was struck an object in the water. They raised PANPAN as the vessel started taking on water. Rescue boats came and helped pump out the water and they then headed back to harbour under tow.
Crew member grabbed anchor chain while it was being hauled. Their fingers were crushed between the roller and chain causing a laceration and bruising.
Logs slipped from deck stow. There was no risk to staff and minor vessel damage occurred.
Ladder secured with small ropes of insufficient diameter.

A recreational vessel failed to give way to passenger vessel. The master of the ferry avoided a collision by making an evasive manoeuvre to starboard. The recreational skipper accepted responsibility for not keeping a proper watch.

A recreational vessel failed to give way to passenger vessel. The master of the ferry avoided a collision by making an evasive manoeuvre to starboard. The recreational skipper accepted responsibility for not keeping a proper watch.
Pilot ladder was stretched and the rungs at bottom of ladder were sloping 30 degrees.
Lower end of handrail on shipside collapsed. Repaired by crew on board.
During driver training, jet boat hit gravel bar and ran aground. They were recovered by a tractor tow.
A passenger from a jet boat tour collapsed on the jetty after the trip. Ambulance were called and the person was taken to hospital for further assessments.
Trainee driver flipped IRB and had to return to shore to reinstate the motor.

The boat was moving slowly, the crew said their engine wasnt operating correctly. They were told to come back to shore so it could be assessed. On their way back in the engine cut out and they were capsized. Both crew and the IRB were recovered.

While pot hauling, pulley got jammed and wind caused vessel to drift and make contact with a submerged rock. The line was released and the starboard engine was used to turn away from the headland. Minor damage to hull was sustained.

When trying to close the bow door, locking indicator lights did not indicate door closed. Heavy weather damage from sea state on the previous crossing had caused bent gussets and misaligned locking pin.
Pilot ladder was stretched on side so no longer horizontal and there were numerous chocks loose.
Vessel was passing through a channel and made contact with a submerged rock, sustaining minor scraping down the port side of hull.
About halfway into the voyage the ferry came off the plane and an engine issue was reported. The vessel continued on with one engine.

Stevedore identified failed access safety structure on the cross decks and lashing bridges. The terminal amended the stowage plans to a max of two boxes high which did not expose the stevedores and lashing gangs to the failure areas.
Propulsion failure of starboard main engine turbo.
The pilot ladder was poor quality with loose chocks causing rotating under foot.
The combination ladders lower stanchion was rigged inboard and no stanchion was rigged outboard or appropriate rope barrier to prevent a fall from heights.

A vessel was leaving the berth and noticed a vessel not under power or anchor. They changed their direction to ensure they passed via the stern to avoid any windage issues. Two divers appeared and the vessel stopped suddenly to avoid contact.
Passenger attempted to jump aboard departing ferry and fell into the water. No injuries were sustained.
Structural failure of an onboard ladder, a hole was found in the web of the longitudinal I-beam ladder. The ladder was removed from the service until repairs were made.
Vessel reported a failure of its communication system

Scaffold decking was being loaded onto a cradle. The punt was listing slightly towards stern. The punt was moved by hand and the cradle began to slowly move towards the stern. This increased the cradle displacement and caused the punt to capsize.

Scaffold decking was being loaded onto a cradle. The punt was listing slightly towards stern. The punt was moved by hand and the cradle began to slowly move towards the stern. This increased the cradle displacement and caused the punt to capsize.
Manropes on pilot ladder were less than the minimum diameter.
Pilot ladder lower trends were not horizontal and had loose chocks particularly on bottom spreader. The tripping line was incorrectly rigged.
While reversing off the ferry loading ramp, bus made contact with the ramp causing a small amount of oil to leak onto ramp. No oil entered the water.

The steering failed in the pilotage area. The master dropped the anchor and called for help to try and fix the issue. They engaged the emergency steering and made their way back to port with another vessel escorting them.
After just boarding ship, passenger tripped, falling and fracturing leg.

During the running-in process for the overhauled diesel generator at 80% load, the engine failed and the piston and conrod of the cylinder were ejected through the crank cover. No injuries were sustained.
Pilot ladder was stretched on one side resulting in the steps sitting at an angle. One of the manropes had a knot at the bottom.
Prior to departure and during main engine warm up, smoke and a small fire was discovered due to faulty alternator. The fire was extinguished immediately.
Cargo ship was on a collision course with another vessel and made no attempt to alter until radioed. They then altered course to port.
Cargo ship was on a collision course with another vessel and made no attempt to alter until radioed. They then altered course to port.

Port bridge wing rudder indicator showed 'hard a port' when 'hard a starboard' had been ordered. The Master declared a defect, that it was not working and claimed that a new one was on order for delivery and fitting the next day.
Pilot ladder was in poor condition with loose chocks and worn ropes.
While retrieving a jet boat from the river, the vessels engine failed and it drifted downstream. A second jet boat provided a tow back to jetty, there was no injuries or damage.
A derailment of first rake of wagons occurred while they were being pushed onto the vessel resulted in wagons entering the water. No spillage or injuries occurred.
While loading stabiliser arm into water, crew member wrapped rope around their hand this resulted in crushing and degloving of the index finger. They were taken to hospital for treatment.
While on passage to New Zealand, vessel lost depth sounder functionality. The depth sounder was not producing an appropriate picture and struggling to stabilise itself in auto mode.

Vessel touched the bottom and throttled back and let the vessel settle on the soft sand bottom approx. 40m inside the river entrance. They stopped both engines and deployed an anchor. They refloated and then went back to sea, before crossing the bar
Rogue wave crashed over fishing vessel and pushed crew against the port side shelter wall. One crew member sustained a sprained ankle, and another a broken tooth.

When entering berth and while in close proximity to other vessels, the vessel lost power to main engine and bow thruster. Smoke and ash emitted from the funnel resulting in the blackout. Tugs were used to safely bring dead vessel to berth.
A strong river current  pushed waka toward buoys, becoming tangled in cables. The crew were brought to shore by coastguard.

While winching boat onto trailer, another boat came from the other side of the slipway and struck the side of the vessel, pushing it into the slipway poles and leaving gouges out of the side that was hit.

Dinghy was struck by wave after its motor stalled, resulting in substantial flooding of the vessel. Vessel occupants evacuated the craft and swam to nearby rocks, after which ocean currents took the vessel out to sea.
While taking on a wave, IRB was pushed backward and hit crest of the wave, ejecting crew and capsizing boat.

While manoeuvring to berth the main engine failed to start, berthing continued with help of tugs. A strong leakage of air from valve was observed and once berthed, crew dismantled the valve and found the gaskets from the piston damaged.
Vessel was seen anchored in the shipping channel with no lights and no reply on channel 16.
During driver training, vessel ran aground while performing a planned turn.
EPIRB accidently activated after being immersed in water. Contact was made via VHF, confirming that it was an accidental activation.
During berthing of the vessel while under control of pilot and two tugs, the vessel made hard contact with the wharf causing large scrapes and dents to the hull.
A near miss occurred when a recreational vessel cut across the ships bow. The vessel blasted their horn five times and attempted to get the attention of the skipper but was ignored.
While under pilotage and with tugs assisting, both shore and vessel fenders were damaged. During the sliding on fenders the fist fender was damaged due to friction between hull and fender.
When coming to berth, vessel made contact with wharf pile. The incident occurred at low RPM upon gear change. There was no damage to the vessel and no injuries.
On preparing to set operating parameters for the bow thruster, the header tank was filled the night before. The day after the header tank was found empty and oil observed in the water.
The engine and bridge telegraph were being used normally but the "stop - start" function were not working so local control was needed. Parts were ordered for arrival  to port.
A collision occurred of single scull and coxless four vessel. The bow of one vessel embedded into the bow of the single scull causing severe damage. One person sustained minor injuries.
An internal hydraulic leak was identified affecting the clutch efficiency. Maintenance team applied clutch lock bolts and completed a full inspection. Replacement parts were ordered.
A complaint was made about surfcasters and white bait fishers, not pulling their lines in when vessels are crossing the river bar.
Vessel hit wave during training at a 45 degree angle which resulted in it overturning.
The driver misjudged a wave during beach race and flipped the boat.
The crane driver was taking a heave into a hatch and caught the top of the coaming which dislodged some of the logs. There were no injuries or damage.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
The pilot ladder was stretched on one side.
When travelling down river, vessel made contact with a submerged object resulting in major damage to propeller and gear housing. The vessel returned to the boat ramp using auxiliary engine.
Pilot ladder was stored incorrectly and in poor condition.

A possible solenoid block may have failed causing one of the four steering pumps to fail. The port side rudder was operating on one pump and there was no loss of operational capability. Spare parts were ordered to the next port.
A foundered personal water craft was connected to a buoy to stop it from sinking. An attempt was made to tow it back with another personal water craft but was unsuccessful.

Vessel came into contact with the wake from their boat which was created from a previous spin. Destabilised, the boat careened sideways towards the bank, its rear starboard side wing making contact with a branch causing slight damage to the wing.
One anchored yacht made contact with another, causing damage to both. It was believed that the mooring anchor had moved due to high winds.
Bow door hydraulic hose burst, causing a release of approximately 40L of oil into the bow door well and overboard.
Spinnaker pole swung around, striking the head of a crew member.
The pilot ladder had loose chocks and lower spreader steps were not horizontal.
Main engine one failed. Fragment of the cylinder liner was found in the area of cylinder number five. A new cylinder liner, piston, connecting rod and other parts were installed on the voyage.
Fishing vessel had no lights on and a power boat came within 2 metres of hitting the arm. The fishing vessel was also discharging sewage into the harbour.
Fishing vessel had no lights on and a power boat came within 2 metres of hitting the arm. The fishing vessel was also discharging sewage into the harbour.
Vessel foundered due to a mechanical failure.
The pilot ladder was worn and had multiple loose chocks which caused steps to rotate under foot.
Due to rough weather a crew member was pinned against the wall by shifting fish cases. The vessel came into Greymouth where the individual was taken to hospital and discharged with minor injuries.
Combination ladder was three metres above the waterline. Minimum of five metres above the waterline required.
Worn ram bushes caused unsteady rudder and steering failure. The passage was unsafe to cross due to conditions and mechanical failures. The vessel anchored and rerouted for repairs.
The pilot ladder had loose chocks allowing steps to rotate under foot. It was replaced with a compliant ladder before disembarking.
Vessel reported a gyrocompass fault
While crossing the Kawhia bar, the vessel took a wave over the bow that dislodged the EPRIB into the sea. Vessel sustained damage to wheelhouse windows.
Tandem Kayak capsized in heavy wind. The kayak was pulled towards land by the passengers and they contacted family on shore. Police were then alerted and both people were rescued.

During outbound transit of container ship, another vessel attempted to pass port to port. Ship horn initially failed to sound, though after a few attempts it sounded and the vessel passed without an incident.

During outbound transit of container ship, another vessel attempted to pass port to port. Ship horn initially failed to sound, though after a few attempts it sounded and the vessel passed without an incident.

A fire broke out in the engine room after cloth fell onto the engine after being hung up to dry. Fire was put out and boat was towed back to port. The boat could not be restarted due to the main engine wiring loom being damaged.
Passengers sustained a minor abrasion from windborne object.

Sparks observed from the ship funnel while running cargo operation. Unburnt carbon deposited on the exhaust system. As a result of this situation more sparks emitted from the funnel. No fire occurred just an excessive amount of sparks.
Vessel grounded on southeast corner of the peninsula. Crew activated EPIRB and were winched aboard rescue helicopter.
While dropping the spinnaker a crew member was knocked overboard by wind gust, sustaining minor injuries. They were picked up from the water and transferred to the ambulance once back on the marina.
IRB caught by wave and capsized. No injuries occurred.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Vessel grounded on riverbank.
Jet boat grounded due to taking the wrong river channel. No injuries or damage occurred.
The pilot ladder construction was poor and the ladder had loose chocks.
IRB capsized during training exercise, resulting in injuries to four passengers.
Due to heavy rain, anchored barge got loose from its moorings and grounded on river back which punctured the hull. A tug was arranged for salvage.
While boarding vessel, pilot had to avoid various lashing wires and equipment hanging over side of vessel due to cargo movement during the voyage.
Spreader released container 0.5m above container below, no injuries occurred.
Vessel propeller entangled by fishing net.
A crewmember was filleting fish when their knife slipped, causing a deep gash to their finger.
During passenger tour, the motor missed twice and then experienced a dead cut.  Spare parts were flown into the area, repairs were made and the tour continued.
Due to large high tide, shoulder belting of vessel got hooked on berth pile. A chainsaw was used to cut pile away so vessel could slide clear.

Vessel received report of a kayaker in distress. They located the kayaker and brought them on board. They were assessed and determined to be in good condition with no injuries or signs of hypothermia.
The pilot ladder was in poor condition.
Grounding of jet boat on river bank due to the driver taking the wrong channel, no damage or injuries occurred.
Wave broke over vessel whilst anchored, this overturned the vessel and sent five people into the water, there were no injuries or damage.

A small fire was observed around portside engine turbo lagging. The fire was extinguished, engine shut down and returned to port on one engine. Investigation found an oil feed line to the turbo had chaffed through and leaked onto the turbo.
A vessel foundered after grounding on rocks.
The vessel was found foundered.
Deck crew member suffered severe back pain while lifting pipes on deck. Ambulance was called to take crew member for further medical assessment.
Vessel made contact with rock in shallow water due to heavy fog and poor visibility.
A trimaran crossed bow of departing ship causing near miss. The vessel appeared to be staying to the western side of channel, then proceeded to cross bow of container ship at close quarters.
Personnel were working vessel lines during departure when the main engine unexpectedly kicked ahead and astern. All personnel were told to stop and keep clear of lines. No injuries.
Jet boat grounded during turn. Passengers were transferred to another vessel and the trip continued. No injuries or damage occurred.
Passenger was descending from the upper deck when they slipped and fell, knocking their head and sustaining a laceration.
Person overboard just outside harbour after vessel was struck by a large wave. Individual recovered from the water and was transported to hospital for treatment of hypothermia.
Starboard gyro repeater not working, maintenance was scheduled.
Crew member reported to master with intense abdominal pain, after consult with DPA the vessel returned to port and crew member was transferred to hospital by ambulance.
While departing, upon increasing engine to slow ahead the main engine slow down alarm sounded, followed by shut down alarm. The chief engineer determined it was due to a faulty sensor.
Pilot ladder stanchions did not have safety/securing pins and the ladder rungs were loose.

Vessel caught by a quartering sea and laid on their starboard side. Two members of charter party were flung across saloon and sustained injuries. Ambulance was called as a precaution and passengers were checked at port.

The starboard engine stopped during the trip. The driver stopped in a safe location and passengers were transferred to a replacement boat without issue. There were no injuries to passengers or damage to the boat.
Contractor working in engine room slipped and pulled the hatch cover down on their arm sustaining bruising and muscle tear.
Routes were not loaded both ECDIS (Electronic Chart Display and Information System) screens, Master and OOW had no working knowledge of how to load routes.
Vessel struck a rock, which led to water ingress. Master grounded the boat to inspect damage and transferred passengers to another vessel. Jetboat returned to base for repair.
Pilot ladder had very loose chocks causing steps to rotate underfoot.
While recovering port anchor, the anchor home engagement gears on actual drive shaft sheared off. This resulted in dropping out six shackles until stopped by brake.

While conducting multibeam soundings in 5m of water at 2 knots, vessel ran aground on a rock for approximately one minute. Vessel was able to reverse into deeper waters with no injuries or significant vessel damage sustained.

During pre departure checks a leak was found coming from casing of the emergency fire pump. The impellor nut inside had come loose and caused the small crack on housing. Repairs were made, the class was informed and the vessel sailed.
Passenger vessel caught out by tide change and nudged another moored vessel. No damage occurred.
Passenger vessel caught out by tide change and nudged another moored vessel. No damage occurred.
Vessels bow crept starboard and the Aft Port Quarter lightly touched the pile on the end of the berth, damaging its outboard.

While disembarking from the boat to the jetty a passenger missed the platform with their foot causing them to fall into the water. Two staff members assisted in getting the passenger out of the water. The passenger did not sustain any injuries.

Wen departing from the berth controllable pitch propeller did respond correctly. Vessel dropped anchor while issue was understood. Vessel raised anchor and proceeded back to the wharf without further incident.
During Jet boat driver training, vessel grounded while doing a U turn. The boat was towed back into deeper water and training continued. No injuries or damage occurred.

Skipper was pushing a dumb barge onto the trailer and caught their finger between the boat and the dumb barge. When the dumb barge moved forward on the trailer it pulled the boat into the side of the barge, crushing their finger tip.
Pilot ladder had unusual access to deck requiring change in hand holds. The ladder reel was secured by a bottle screw arrangement.
Jet boat ran aground, the wind gust reduced steering capability.
Injury to incoming crew member slipped and fell onto a closed hatch resulting in broken rib.

Launch sank at the gravel ramp at Port Motueka due to not being tied up properly.  A very minor spill of diesel was noted at the rear of the vessel. At low tide the water was released and remainder pumped out, no oil was present.

On departure, the main engine was unable to operate above 50 RPM from Sticking Point outbound. On arrival, the same issue occurred, however repairs were undertaken prior to departure. Vessel proceeded at reduced RPM with tug on standby at wharf.
A crew member was medically evacuated from vessel with suspected pancreatitis.
An aluminium pontoon vessel flipped throwing a passenger hard against the side resulting in a broken arm. Coastguard were called to undertake rescue.
During approach to port, pilot determined that vessel's gyrocompass was faulty. Tugs secured to vessel and berthed without incident and master informed that the issue needed to be fixed.
Pilot witnessed delay to vessel departure from port due to an undetermined engine issue. During its rescheduled departure, engine required multiple starts.

Vessel was shooting trawl gear when the gearbox overheated. Crew hauled trawl gear back on board while fault was assessed. Following assessment, decision was made to have vessel towed back to port rather than risk further damage to the vessel.
Event Location: Bay of Plenty, East of Red Mercury Island

Brief Description: A low level alarm sounded for the hydraulic tank due to an electrical problem, there was no physical issue with the steering motor operation. One of the three fire pumps was not operational due to a faulty transformer.
A crew member was injured when the join on a copper pipe separated and one end scratched them in the left eye. Crew member received medical assistance at hospital.
Boat was left moored after a tour and a few children are thought to have been playing in the boat while unattended. It was noticed that the fuse for the RPM gauge was missing.
Passenger missed hand rail and slipped onto their knee. Crew and passengers on board assessed the injury and the vessel returned to port for the passenger to receive medical treatment.
Diver sustained a twisted knee when entering water. First aid was administered and it was then decided to take the injured person back to the mainland.

Passenger on board vessel had a medical issue where they felt unwell, became pale and sick, and fell unconscious for 90 seconds. The vessel made its way to the nearest wharf where a helicopter was organised to meet them.
The vessel experienced steering issues while under power. Tugs were made aware of the situation however, they were stood down as the situation was resolved.
Event Location: North of Cape Jackson, Cook Strait

Brief Description: Bosun's locker on trawl deck caught on fire. The emergency fire drill procedure followed and the fire was extinguished.

The steering gear was observed to be responding sluggishly, the pilot ordered the vessel to anchor. The number two steering block drive had broken metal pieces inside of it. Spare parts were requested.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
During rough conditions, crew member's arm fractured after being caught by main sheet traveller.
During Pilot transfer boarding ladder caught around cleat which damaged the pilot ladder.
Crew member went overboard during a manoeuvre. Crew member recovered from the water after two attempts by the vessel, with no injuries sustained.
While shooting a fishing net it became entangled on the rudder and then caught on the propeller. Diver cleared propeller and retrieved net.
Vessel capsized outside of bar. Both occupants were collected by an unknown vessel and taken to shore. Both occupants were taken to hospital and subsequently released.
During routine inspection Rescue Boat engine failed to start due to broken starter coil. Repairs were arranged.
Log slipped from the side of vessel and landed on the wharf during log loading. No injuries or damage were evident.
Jet boat crash requiring helicopter evacuation to hospital.
Vessel reported drop leak from the port side RAM seal of steering gear. Steering gear reported to be in normal operation with repairs arranged.
Jet boat made contact with gravel bank and the side of boat was dented. Passenger put hand out to brace themselves and fractured their wrist. They were taken to A&E for treatment.
A call was received to rescue a six metre runabout during bad weather. While under tow the vessel sank and was towed to beach for salvage. All occupants safely returned to shore on rescue vessel.

A boat heading out across the bar was hit by a two metre wave and tipped three occupants out. The boat continued and the occupants spent half hour in water prior to rescue. They were wearing lifejackets, two people had moderate injuries and one minor

Vessel capsized during Waikato bar crossing. Rescue services were dispatched, with two passengers rescued from the water by rescue craft, while another was brought ashore by a recreational boat in the vicinity.
Passenger being towed behind jetboat on a mat slipped, falling into the water. They were taken ashore and assessed.
Event Location: Finlay Park Adventure Camp, Waikato River

Brief Description: Stevedore was pinned between a hand railing and upright stanchion in a walkway during vessel loading. The railing collapsed inwards towards the walkway, which in turn contacted the Stevedore. They were transferred to ED, sustaining minor injuries.

Vessel was blown out and away from wharf by a sudden wind gust, which resulted in the gangway sliding and dropping off the edge of the vessel. Damage occurred to the gangway and ships rails. No people were injured.
The high temperature engine pump was leaking. Repairs were organised by the vessel master.

Leaving port the vessel got caught by the tide forcing them to lay along side another vessel. In order to get free of other vessel it had to move out from its berth so they became free of it and could sail.

The boat driver was heading downstream and misread the river, while trying to manoeuvre out of a channel they grounded the boat while completing a planning "U" turn. There were no customers in the boat, there was no injury to the driver and no damage
Failure of port anchor winch coupling. Anchor began to run away before being secured by three crew on deck.
There was shore break present which was difficult to navigate, and the driver miss timed a wave and hit a dumping wave at the wrong time in the IRB.

Driver of RWC didn't have arms locked properly and hit lower jaw on handlebars after impact with a wave. This resulted in them losing a cap on their upper canine tooth and a small laceration to lower jaw.

The strong tide became apparent and the 30 degree turn, alongside talking with the crew on the vessel at the time led to the vessel getting stuck on a rock with the tide going out quickly. Hours later at high tide the vessel then re floated.
Vessel grounded on sand bar. The motors were tilted up and the vessel was manoeuvred off the sand. There was no damage identified to the motors/vessel.
Vessel hit underwater object, which ripped off the engine and transom. The vessel was then abandoned due to the sudden ingress of water. Everyone on board made it back to shore with no injuries.
Yacht was abandoned after the engine failed and sail was damaged, skipper sent a Pan Pan and then activated a beacon and was subsequently rescued by helicopter.
A double rowing boat were travelling on the wrong side of the river which was obstructing the passage of another rowing boat.
Training jet boat driver ran a ground after missing correct channel, there were no injuries or damage.
Vessel lost main engine power to a failure and required a tow to the harbour.
Bulk carrier's number one ECDIS (Electronic Chart Display and Information System) was not working correctly. Ship applied for berthing with the number two ECDIS.
Crew member slipped on ice in vessel's fish hold and fell onto their back, sustaining a minor injury.
A kayaker fell into the water after struggling to stay on their kayak. Staff assisted with the rescue.

Vessel's VHF radio started locking on to random channels during scan function causing a lot of interference. After performing an assessment it became clear the vessel's cameras were causing interference.

The skipper was struck in the face by a fish and suffered an allergic reaction. Medical services were consulted and the decision was made to proceed to shore for the injured party to receive treatment.
The owner of a launch attempted to ram another boat after an earlier disagreement with the owner. Police and the harbourmaster were notified.
Hoisting wire snapped on the number four ship crane.
Engine manifold overheated. Vessel ran with slow pitch and rpm, they diverted to port to undertake repairs.
Vessel on route to new Zealand had a x-band radar fail. The master arranged for repairs to be undertaken when the vessel arrived at port.
Fuel pump failed causing engine failure. Coastguard were contacted and the vessel was safely towed back to the marina.

During the final approach to berth the port main ramp chain parted. The vessel was stopped then reversed slightly to create a reverse momentum, so the situation could be assessed. The starboard chain was holding, the vessel proceed slowly.
While arriving at anchorage, skipper observed that the vessel's echo sounder was not functioning.
Pilot ladder had varnished steps. The deck officer was advised of the need for replacement.
Multiple jet boats passed vessel at anchor at high speed, causing a large wake and destabilising and flooding the vessel. The skippers all ignored hand signals to slow down.

Jetboat passenger seated in the front row slid along their seat during a sharp turn, causing their head to impact against the vessel dashboard, resulting in the passenger sustaining a cut above their eye. Basic first aid was administered on site.
Vessel grounded in shallow waters Skipper managed to exit the boat and push it to a deeper area and take off. No passengers exited the boat.

Boat hit submerged log at a speed of approx. 15 knots. The boat was immediately pulled out of gear on impact. Once checked, the vessel continued with caution. The boat and passengers were checked and there were no injuries or damage.

Yacht club patrol boat came into contact with a moored vessel during training, there were no injuries. The impact caused a tear in the outer fabric of the pontoon. There was no major loss of seaworthiness and the moored vessel was undamaged.
IRB hit wave side on which resulted in one crew member going overboard, no injuries and no damage occurred.
One of the chocks failed causing one side of the rung to drop on the pilot ladder.
Helmsperson overcorrected whilst turning causing crew to fall overboard. Passing fishing boat picked up crew and returned them to the wharf.
The accommodation ladder platform was too low and steps were observed to have been varnished.
Skipper lost control of the vessel side on to a wave, resulting in its capsize. They were in shallow water and driver and crew were unharmed.
Vessel made contact with the wharf during departure.
The emergency generator breaker on the oil tanker broke. The vessel was not able to start on auto.
Aluminium end plate broke, metal fatigue had not been detected during maintenance checks as the procedure did not remove the swivel from the davit to check underneath.
While at low speed the vessel became stuck on a sand bar in the river - crew self recovered - there was no damage to the vessel or the crew.

Skipper observed crew working on a floating platform at the stern of their vessel which was going to be in the way for their arrival to the port. The crew were made aware of the situation and cleared before the vessel proceeded.

Vessel with engine failure was being assisted by the Coastguard when rough conditions resulted in the two vessels colliding, no injuries and minor damage. The skipper continued with the manoeuvre and checked the damage when it was safe.
Passenger vessel mooring/docking lines slipped, and vessel came away. Vessel was recovered by skipper.
Crew member was spiked by a toxic barb whilst processing a fish.
While bringing the Jetski into wharf, contact was made sustaining superficial damage.
Near miss between a yacht and another vessel heading towards it, yacht increased heading to windward to pass clear of other vessel.
IRB capsized during driver training.

The flare of the bow struck the concrete top of the fender. The engines were put astern to back off the berth with continued thrust to starboard which cleared the fender. Ship berthed with no further incidents.
Launch struck rocks and was taking on water. Coastguard attended, made temporary repairs and towed vessel back to the wharf.
A wave hit the IRB while it was side on to the wave in the process of turning, causing a capsize.
Jet boat stopped in deep flow but then drifted backwards and ran aground, passengers were transferred onto spare boat. There were no injuries or damage.

The gearbox disengaged and the engine went to full throttle. Skipper stopped the main engine and deployed the anchor. The plugs had become dislodged by an unsecured empty 20ltr container, the throttles were corrected and vessel resumed passage.
The vessel suffered a blackout, this was identified as a gearbox pump overheating. The partial blackout was rectified and a gear pump was replaced.
A deliberate collision between two vessels was staged during a training exercise. The intended contact point was missed and one of the vessels sustained a small amount of damage.
A deliberate collision between two vessels was staged during a training exercise. The intended contact point was missed and one of the vessels sustained a small amount of damage.
Waves hit kayak side on. Kayaker was knocked overboard but was able to reach nearby rocks and call for assistance.
Crew member received a minor electric shock after touching water inside the sea strainers.

During the departure of a container ship a pleasure craft approached and passed around 20m from stern of tug. Tug was well lit and providing towage and sounded sound signal to alert the vessel however no action was taken.

During the departure of a container ship a pleasure craft approached and passed around 20m from stern of tug. Tug was well lit and providing towage and sounded sound signal to alert the vessel however no action was taken.
Jet boat grounded after an attempted crossover in the wrong channel. Passengers were transferred to dry land and reboarded into a spare boat.

As tanker approached jetty it was noticed there were divers in the water next to and under the jetty. The pilot was informed. The person was met by police and made aware about the dangers of being in the vicinity of tugs and a large vessel.
The launch engine failed causing the vessel to drift onto sand and close to rocks. Coastguard responded and towed the vessel to fuel berth.
Water speed log started to experience an intermittent signal. Vessel relied on GPS and DGPS units for ground speed and arranged for spare parts delivery for repairs.
Driver fell out of the IRB after momentarily loss of concentration.
Kayaker rescued from water by nearby yacht after their kayak capsized. Kayaker was transported to hospital for treatment for hypothermia.
Vessel operator approached wave at excessive speed, causing IRB to roll over and ejecting crew from the vessel.

The auxiliary engine was out of service and generator No. 3 was taken off service, due to damage to the connecting rod bearing cylinder. Dispensation was granted until repairs can be made as the vessel was travelling on route to port.
Evacuation of stevedores due to excessive smoke and fumes entering vessel hatches and cranes. Smoke and fumes believed to have been caused by the ship's boiler and engine ignition.
Cargo ship made contact with shore container crane whilst undertaking final positioning. The crane was left in position until a structural assessment was taken.

Miscommunication between jet boat drivers during a training exercise resulted in one driver on the wrong side of the river and having to ground vessel on riverbank to avoid a collision. Driver able to exit vessel and manoeuvre it into deeper waters.
IRB was positioned incorrectly when hit by wave, causing vessel to roll. The vessel was not facing straight into the waves and did not have enough speed to match the energy of the wave.
During berthing, vessel's messenger line was dragged by a strong current into the propeller. Divers arranged to inspect and clear fouled propeller.
Miscommunication between operators of approaching passenger ferries regarding which side of the passage each vessel should occupy to pass the other led to a near miss.
A passenger sustained two fractured ankles.
Passenger caught their finger in the door resulting in partial amputation. They were sent to the hospital for treatment.
Whilst approaching berth, the deckhand spotted a person in the water holding onto a floating tyre fender. Person was retrieved uninjured and returned to wharf.
Coastguard vessel experienced propulsion failure while responding to a vessel that was drifting toward rocks. Engines were restarted and the Coastguard vessel was able to resume the rescue operation.
Commercial charter vessel was rescuing a recreational vessel whose engine had broken down and had drifted onto rocks. Charter boat brought passengers on board, then towed vessel back to shore.
IRB driver misjudged wave, and as all three crew were on one side of the boat it overbalanced and capsized.

Charter vessel with passengers on board hit a rock, the bilge alarm sounded and the vessel started taking on water. A mayday was called and the vessel proceeded to shore to beach the vessel. Passengers transferred to land.
Crew member's foot was caught between dropping rail and fixed rail. Medevac was organised to remove the crewmember from the vessel for treatment.
Passenger lost their balance and fell, sustaining a fractured femur. The passenger was assessed on board and then disembarked and transferred to hospital.
Contractor on board vessel performing electrical services failed to follow 'Lock out/Tag Out' (LOTO) safety procedures.
Crew member was guiding on wires onto a net roller while hauling when their hand was caught between the drum and wire, crushing their right hand.
Jet boat grounded in shallow water after a misjudged spin.

Vessel skipper observed a small slick on the surface of the water. Inspection revealed a faulty steering mechanism, leading to fluid leaking from the vessel. The boat was towed back to port where repairs were undertaken.

The skipper noticed that the port thruster was not clutched and the pilot was informed. The pilotage was completed, tests were conducted to confirm they could not clutch in the port thruster. The pressure sensor was at fault and was repaired.

A full grab of palm kernel was taken out of hold by a stevedore. The grab was over the side deck of the vessel, the grab released all of the product contained within onto the side deck and wharf. A minimal amount of product also entered the harbour.
Skipper noticed jet boat's steering was stiff, they made the decision to return to the jetty.
Boat driver was performing a planned turn but turned slightly too sharp causing the boat to lose speed and beach.
The skipper jumped over board as they noticed a vessel coming towards them at a high speed. Skipper jumped into the water to avoid the vessel, which avoided a collision with the boat.
A skipper noticed a dark shape in the water and swerved to avoid contact, it was a small boat with no visible lights.

Vessel gave five blasts and had to reduce speed in order to avoid a collision with another vessel which passed in front of their bow. The vessel continued on with speed and ignored the contact efforts the vessel made.

Crew was putting the stern night line on after the evening charter. It was stuck on something on the wharf, when they tried to pull it off, it came loose and crew member lost balance, falling in the harbour.
During transit to NZ, crew member fell into cargo hold and sustained a broken ankle, requiring medical evacuation to hospital.

The grapple fell onto wharf side back onto the trailer. It was suspected that the hoisting wire had failed but after investigation it was found out that the newly installed gear box was faulty and not holding the hoisting drum under a load.
Jet boat driver alleged by observer to have failed to observe local rules relating to entry points of waterways.
Passenger was experiencing heart burn and chest pains, emergency services were called. They were evacuated from the vessel via helicopter and taken to hospital.
Jet boat driver and trainee were practising a spin when the boat spun at an incorrect angle and stopped on rocks, there were no injuries and only minor damage to boat.
Skipper detected smoke emanating from exhaust stack. Engines and battery chargers were shut down and smoke disappeared. Vessel was towed back to shore and starter motor solenoid replaced.
Crewmember caught a foreign body inside their left eyelid while cooking. Treated with eye drops and no further complications were reported.
D ring twist locks on hatch lids fell onto dock narrowly missing stevedores unlashing below. Crew removed hazards from above and under lid area before recommencing operations.
Crew member landed awkwardly on the bottom of the boat, breaking their hand in four places.

There was a malfunction of the engine remote control telegraph on the starboard side bridge wing. The control of the main engine was switched to main control point on the central console on the bridge. The mooring operations were completed safely.

Passenger fell down stairs, twisting their foot and sustaining a left ankle fracture. Duty paramedic attended the scene and conveyed them to the medical centre for treatment. They were taken ashore at the next port.

Truck driver onboard vessel returned to their vehicle and discovered that a fire had ignited within the truck cab. The fire was contained to the vehicle's cab and no damage was sustained to the vessel or other nearby vehicles.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Capsize of hired kayak by customer on a guided river tour. Rescued by tour guide, with no injuries sustained.
Vessel was alongside the wharf, it was noted that one pile was leaning over. The vessel made slight contact with the piles, the pile had failed due to extreme deterioration of the metal casing.
Passenger vessel experienced loss of power on the starboard engine, due to an exhaust coupling that broke. The skipper shut down the starboard engine and returned to the wharf on one engine.
As a load was being lifted the wake of a large ship caused the vessel to roll towards the wharf accelerating the swing of the load where it struck the back of the truck and dented it.

Boat was rotating off pontoon in forward gear. As the skipper went from forward to reverse, there was no response. Anchor was deployed and the vessel was re secured via the docking lines to the wharf. The vessel was towed back to the marina.
Passenger slipped while ascending stairs. In attempting to break their fall they put out their hand and sustained a wrist fracture.
Tourism vessel approached rock wall to observe seals. With swell and another vessel blocking the exit, vessel made contact with the rock wall.
Jetski observed travelling in excess of the speed limit.
Employee was unlashing a container on deck of a container ship and dropped an object on their right hand, this resulted in a fracture to their middle finger.

Steering failed due to splitting the rudders in port wing the starboard rudder was noted to move to hard port position. Starboard engine was stopped at this point, and the vessel manoeuvred clear of berth using port engine, rudder and bow thrusters.
Two passengers jumped from the vessel while at anchor, contrary to the instructions of the skipper. They climbed back up and returned to the vessel.
Pilot ladder was worn with multiple loose chocks.

Buddy pair of divers did not surface at the expected time, the skipper made a call for assistance and the pair were located safely after they activated their personal locator beacon. No injuries were sustained.
Chief engineer fell off the catwalk (approximately 1m in height) while transporting oil drums, landing on their right shoulder on deck.
Passenger on board cruise ship fell and fractured their leg.

Driver lost control of IRB, resulting in a crew member falling overboard due to unsecure footing. When the driver turned around to collect crew member, the propeller grazed the crewmembers leg, resulting in a minor laceration.
During a training exercise IRB crew came up beside people swimming in the water, one of whose rescue tubes lanyard became entangled in the propeller. There were no injuries or damage.

Tug was pushing barge onto landing when a southerly front hit. Tug was unable to hold barge and attempted to tow barge away from the landing, the barge was then pushed sideways onto the beach. Tug then towed barge off and returned it to the wharf.
40ft boat sustained structural damage in heavy weather, with two out of three crew sustaining injuries after the vessel rolled off a wave. Coastguard rescued crew and vessel drifted ashore.
Driver fell out of IRB after it went over a wave, their colleague launched second IRB, rescued driver and towed first IRB back to shore. No injuries or damage occurred.
Passenger attempted to step from the tender embarkation area to the tender boat, fell forward and landed on their knee, fracturing their knee cap.

After servicing, the vessel needed to be operated on a single engine as there was no water cooling in the starboard engine. Vessel returned to berth and service technician recalled. Keyway was found in pipes and impellor had not been operating.

Wind gusts broke bollard causing two mooring ropes to fall into the water and one rope to snap. It was believed that a piece of the broken bollard sliced the mooring line. No injuries or damage that occurred as a result of the incident.
Jet boat driver beached on a shallow bar after following another boat too closely, passengers were transferred to other boats. There were no injuries or damage.
Two vessels had a near miss after one was cleared to leave port, and the other also attempted to move at the same time. Contact was avoided with evasive manoeuvring.

Person on a hired kayak paddled outside the boundary area, was caught by a gust of wind and capsized.
Tug Master noticed there was a steady stream of bubbles coming from below the waterline of ship, it was assessed as a possible crack in the ballast tank.
Parasail was struck by gust upon landing and one of the passengers clipped their toe on the side of the boat. A crew member who reached out to help jammed their finger.
One individual injured in jet boat crash.
The skipper took the vessel off autopilot and altered course to enter harbour, they became distracted vessel ran aground at Lighthouse point.
Yacht hit a sandbank and began taking on water. The local fire brigade and coastguard provided assistance, rescuing the crew and bringing the yacht aground so it wouldn't sink.
Fatal recreational boating accident.

A deckhand was holding a Gilson hook and tripped over the side of the arena and fell, their hand caught on the hook. The deckhands finger was examined, dressed and taped on board before being taken to hospital for further treatment.

There was uncontrolled discharge of ammonia on board the trawler whilst trawler was berthed. Alarms sounded and crew evacuated the vessel and mustered on the wharf. Crew were evacuated, with one crew member suffering burns to one eye.

Vessel made distress call after hitting rocks. Their EPIRB was activated to confirm the position of the vessel. Coastguard responded and they assessed the vessel. There was no water ingress and they towed the vessel to its berth.
Vessel lost propulsion amid breaking waves and could not be restarted, resulting in the vessel capsizing.

Person launching a jet ski got finger caught between the RWC hull and the rollers at the front of the trailer when a wave pushed the vessel back up the trailer. They were taken to hospital for treatment.
Observer participating in IRB driver training was ejected from the vessel during an on-water manoeuvre, resulting in an injury.
Contractor working on the vessel lost balance and fell off the vessel into the water.

Container ship had a technical fault with the GPS equipment. There was an electrical technician sailing with the vessel who was able to switch the GPS over in event of failure. A replacement part was ordered.

An alarm sounded for the ballast water flow sensor when in idle mode. Vessel staff investigated and checked the source of fault and thereafter informed office to seek remote assistance. Crew were unable to rectify the flow sensor problem.
Jet boat hit shallow bar on outside of corner and beached.
Two kayakers capsized while attempting to avoid a group individuals in the river bend.

Passenger vessel was parked next to an iceberg when the a section of ice broke off, falling onto the deck of the vessel. The boat's windshield and back seat were damaged and three passengers were injured.
Container ship was conducting engine mobilisation when the inside crane broke and dropped the head of the engine down onto the engine body.
Engine cut out multiple times causing the IRB to rollover after being caught by a wave, engine was subsequently submerged.
Oil tanker had propulsion engine failure. There was a fault with the DC charging fault, power was available at seventy percent of usual capacity.
Jet boat grounded after attempted spin manoeuvre, the crew pushed boat back into deeper water.

Skipper of recreational vessel involved in altercation with operator of charter vessel, who is alleged to have acted in violent and threatening manner.
During cargo operations, minor HFO spillage on the tank-top was found. All fuel was transferred as a precaution and there was no external oil pollution.

Crane operator loading a container into hatch narrowly missed a crewmember traversing the hatch lid.
IRB operator undergoing driver training misjudged approach to wave and rolled vessel.
Kayak capsized in large swells. The kayaker became separated from their kayak and was rescued by Coastguard after they activated their personal locator beacon.
Crew were tightening lashing wire when the turnbuckle broke. The released lashing wire struck the ankle of a crew member, who was transported to hospital for treatment.

Container ship experienced engine failure prior to entry into port. The generator No 3 was taken-off service due to damage of connecting road bearing cylinder No 6. Dispensation was granted as corrective/preventive actions were implemented.
A crewmember reported headaches and dizziness after hitting their head on machinery.
Large catamaran yacht ran over the top of a smaller vessel at anchor in harbour entrance.

Vessel operator fell overboard while fishing. Individual was unable to re-board their vessel and was rescued after spending approximately 23 hours in the water.
Ammonia suction hose on plate freezer failed resulting in release of ammonia into the factory. Leak repaired with no injuries sustained.
Witness states they saw a vessel missing a turn on a routine journey causing the ship to stop and reverse. Witness unsure how close the vessel came to land.
Auto slow alarm sounded during departure. Pitch automatically reduced. Crew unable to determine cause of the fault.

Person observed a jet ski driving at high speeds picking up and dropping people off on shore.

Passenger on charter vessel fell off their seat and sustained a fractured elbow, requiring surgery.

Vessel hatch lid on which stevedore was standing collapsed, causing the stevedore to fall two meters to the deck.
RCCNZ notified that a vessel had lost steering and was drifting towards rocks. Police and Lifeflight rescue helicopter attended, and located the vessel, which was then towed to the marina.
Jetboat glanced a pillar while completing as S shaped turn through a dam. No injuries and only cosmetic damage to boat.
Loading ferry with rail wagons - one wagon derailed.  No injuries or damage.

Engine no. 2 propulsion failure. Returned to port on starboard engine and repairs undertaken.
Boat at anchor with two divers in the water. Passengers on board noticed smoke coming from behind dash. Fire spread and engulfed cabin. All onboard evacuated and swam to shore.
Heavy rain and swell combined to swamp tender and sink it. Salvage completed immediately.
Passenger ferry engine overheated and was shut down immediately. Vessel was towed back to mooring so mechanic could complete engine checks.
